title: Walsingham Class of 2018 to remain 'one voice' after graduation
content: Walsingham Academy’s class of 2018 graduated with smiles and wearing all white.    The class of 44 graduated in a small ceremony on Saturday.    The class earned $5.1 million in merit scholarships.    “It is important that we go into the world with confidence and a strong sense of self and trust in the lessons that we have learned from our families and here at Walsingham Academy,” said valedictorian Julia Vidlak said.    “We are all going in different directions, but remember that the memories of our past will guide us into the events of our futures.”    Ashley Luck  Walsingham Academy class of 2018 valedictorian Julia Vidlak  Walsingham Academy class of 2018 valedictorian Julia Vidlak (Ashley Luck)     Co-salutatorian Gregory Peterson said Walsingham has great things to offer to students, but that’s not what makes the academy.    “Walsingham is a good school, there are a lot of hard classes offered, the athletics program is strong,” Peterson said. “But none of these things make Walsingham great. Walsinhgam is great because of the people, our class is close and we all work together. Every single one of you was an important part of my experience”    Co-salutatorian Grace Vidlak said she will remember serving the community during her time at Walsingham.    “They taught us human dignity, compassion and respect,” she said. “… As we go on, always remember to treat others with respect and to smile at one another.”    The graduates performed “One Voice” by Ruth Moody, symbolizing that they will remain together as classmates after graduation.    Academy president Sister Mary Jeanne Oesterle and upper school director Angie Baker looked on as the graduates made their way across the stage and bowed or curtsied before receiving their diplomas.
